answers: Implemented correctly, one needs to perform one floating point addition and one division for each pixel on average
There is one global memory read per pixel. Since the image is monochromatic this corresponds to one floating point read.
There is one global memory write per pixel. Since the image is monochromatic this corresponds to one floating point read.
One can represent the image as unsigned characters. This means that each pixel occupies one byte compared to 4 required for single precision floating point.
